header.p: If trombone is my principal instrument, then the keyboard is my secondary instrument. I began playing organ for The Runaround, and have been playing since.

text.p: I bought this organ from a guy in Connecticut (I forget his name). Drove there in my 1995 Saturn SW1 wagon with a trailer attached. At the time it was the farthest I had ever driven.
This thing is a beast. I have since built a new case for her, and I intend to build another, even better case in the future.

The RT series features 32 foot pedals (as opposed to 25 on the B series), as well as a "pedal solo" assembly. I couldn't quite figure out the pedal solo portion because it didn't really work, but from what I can guess, it was basically a component which would add 16', 8', 4', 2', and other harmonics on top of the normal pedal stop (which is either a 16' or 32' stop, I'm not sure). At any rate, I removed the pedal solo amplifier and the entire foot pedal assembly from the organ to reduce the overall weight. It never worked correctly anyway.

I bought this keyboard in the early days of
The Runaround. At the time, we had no keyboard player but decided that we needed one, and so I jumped at the idea of diversifying my talents. I bought the Electro 2 because that was what Julian O'Brien played with Mile 21, and I have not once regretted this decision. The Nord Electro 2 models the Hammond A100, as well as several other electromechanical keyboards from the vintage era.

This is the Electro 2 without the keyboard--it is just a rack-mountable sound module. I bought this on a whim thinking I could use it side-by-side with
Margaret to create a piano/organ combination, or dual organ combination. I haven't found a good MIDI controller to go with it yet.
